headline.main: TALENTED ACTORS ENRICH A FINE SCRIPT

results.snippet: Let's get one thing straight immediately: James L. Brooks's ''Terms of Endearment'' is not a perfect movie. This comedy about a middle-class Texas widow, her daughter and their respective lovers sort of meanders around a plot that covers...
results.lead_paragraph: Let's get one thing straight immediately: James L. Brooks's ''Terms of Endearment'' is not a perfect movie. This comedy about a middle-class Texas widow, her daughter and their respective lovers sort of meanders around a plot that covers approximately 30 years. It contains one more fatal illness than you may want to witness, and every now and then Mr. Brooks's sit-com background (''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' ''Rhoda,'' ''Lou Grant,'' Taxi,'' etc.) is apparent in the film's inability to resist a fast response that may not be entirely in character with the person responding. All of this, however, is beside the point. ''Terms of Endearment'' must be one of the most engaging films of the year, to be cherished as much for the low-pressure way in which it operates (no mammoth star egos to contend with, no major themes to intimidate) as for the fact that it contains what are possibly the best performances ever given by Shirley MacLaine and Jack Nicholson.

headline.main: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY

results.snippet: Spacelab GetsUp to Business   After keeping fingers crossed and pocketbooks open for a decade, European nations finally saw their $1 billion Spacelab carried into orbit last week by the shuttle Columbia. The bus-sized cannister, chockablock with...
results.lead_paragraph: Spacelab GetsUp to Business After keeping fingers crossed and pocketbooks open for a decade, European nations finally saw their $1 billion Spacelab carried into orbit last week by the shuttle Columbia. The bus-sized cannister, chockablock with experiments, sent a torrent of data back to earth. ''Columbia is America's dream - if that dream doesn't work, ours won't either,'' the director of Spacelab's prime contractor in West Germany said in 1981. At week's end, the mission had developed a few kinks - the film jammed in a special mapping camera and an electron gun failed - but things were still going well enough to help heal some of the diplomatic wounds caused by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's long struggle with shuttle development. West Germans picked up more than half of Spacelab's cost and also placed a Stuttgart physicist on board this premier flight.

headline.main: DARK HORSE FROM CALIFORNIA

results.snippet: Robert Lindsey is The New York Times's bureau chief in Los Angeles. By Robert Lindsey   ARKNESS IS GIVing way to dawn as a tall, gaunt man crosses Massachusetts Avenue a few blocks from the United States Capitol. He stops at a public park, lies...
results.lead_paragraph: Robert Lindsey is The New York Times's bureau chief in Los Angeles. By Robert Lindsey ARKNESS IS GIVing way to dawn as a tall, gaunt man crosses Massachusetts Avenue a few blocks from the United States Capitol. He stops at a public park, lies down on the grass, stretches for several minutes, rolls over and stands on his head. A black poodle, unleashed and curious, runs over and sniffs at the upside-down man who wants to be President of the United States. But the man ignores the dog, and after a while it wanders away. The man gets up and walks toward a dirt path near the edge of the park. After a moment, there's a perceptible quickening of his stride, a pause, and then he starts to run. Soon he is sprinting down the track with startling speed and energy for a man of 69, his head held erect and his arms pumping back and forth like levers on a machine. After running about 150 yards, he pulls up at an invisible finish line, walks back and does it again - not once, but three times.

headline.main: READING FOR WORK AND PLEASURE

results.snippet: For the Christmas issue, The Book Review asked a number of prominent people what in the last year was the most important book they read for their work and what was the best book they read for pleasure, with a few words of explanation. Clifford...
results.lead_paragraph: For the Christmas issue, The Book Review asked a number of prominent people what in the last year was the most important book they read for their work and what was the best book they read for pleasure, with a few words of explanation. Clifford Geertz said he imagined a number of respondents might be uncomfortable with the useful/pleasurable distinction, and, in fact, the distinction was ignored more than once. Also, some respondents ignored our superlatives and gave us more than the requested two titles, although the extras were welcome. About the ''few words of explanation,'' some replies had none, while others more than made up for them. Ronald Reagan President of the United States John Hackett's novel, ''The Third World War: August 1985,'' Joanna Stratton's ''Pioneer Women'' and David Lamb's ''The Africans.'' Robert A. Caro Author

headline.main: BRIEFING

results.snippet: Hawkeye Hustings    Local pride alone does not account   for the fervent political battle   being waged by Iowa Democrats to retain their state's position as the scene of the earliest Presidential selection event of 1984. The Iowa caucuses,...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: Hawkeye Hustings Local pride alone does not account for the fervent political battle being waged by Iowa Democrats to retain their state's position as the scene of the earliest Presidential selection event of 1984. The Iowa caucuses, birthing-rite for Jimmy Carter in 1976 though not for George Bush in 1980, have become a major source of publicity and income for the state. Witness the fact that the Iowa Democratic Party has scheduled a media seminar next week to explain to reporters how to cover the caucuses, which will be held Feb. 20 if the Democratic National Committee consents to that date, which it has not. Journalists who go to Des Moines Dec. 15 will receive lectures on state political history, including one called ''Why Iowa Should Be First,'' observe a mock caucus and walk through the tabulation center that will reveal the caucus victors. Tuition for the seminar, to cover ''a noon banquet, conference refreshments and all conference materials,'' is $20 for out-of-state reporters and $10 for Iowans. Native newsmen, it would appear, eat and drink less than outlanders.

headline.main: ASTRONAUT MENDS A SHUTTLE CAMERA

results.snippet: Like a tourist going back to a darkened motel room to fix a jammed camera, Dr. Robert A. R. Parker turned out the lights inside the space shuttle Columbia today, zipped himself inside his sleeping bag and freed the stuck film in a mapping camera. ...
results.lead_paragraph: Like a tourist going back to a darkened motel room to fix a jammed camera, Dr. Robert A. R. Parker turned out the lights inside the space shuttle Columbia today, zipped himself inside his sleeping bag and freed the stuck film in a mapping camera. One more of the several equipment malfunctions of the earth-orbiting mission had been overcome, and the scientists aboard the shuttle's Spacelab resumed taking high-resolution pictures in a test of the potential of making maps from space. Much of the photography was of Western Europe. Mission officials described Dr. Parker as the shuttle's ''repairman extraordinaire.'' Several days ago, he used a screwdriver to fix the reel of a high-speed data recorder, restoring a capability to store vast amounts of scientific data collected when the Columbia is out of range of the tracking satellite that is its primary communication link to earth.

headline.main: SPACELAB, STILL IN ORBIT, ALREADY DEEMED A SUCCESS

results.snippet: Two scientists conducted a fluid-physics experiment last week under the most unusual circumstances. They worked shoulder to shoulder, or so it seemed, and yet they were thousands of miles apart in distinctly different fields of gravity. Their...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD , Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two scientists conducted a fluid-physics experiment last week under the most unusual circumstances. They worked shoulder to shoulder, or so it seemed, and yet they were thousands of miles apart in distinctly different fields of gravity. Their experiment and their methods typified a new way of conducting scientific research in a new kind of laboratory beyond the earth in the endlessly mysterious environment of space. Ulf Merbold, a West German physicist, was the one actually in space. He floated in the virtual absence of gravity inside the earth-orbiting Spacelab, the large research facility in the space shuttle Columbia's cargo bay. His attention was focused on the fluid- physics module in a cabinet positioned almost exactly at the spaceship's center of mass. None of the other five crewmen were stirring, so as not to disturb the experiment with any vibrations. John F. Padday, a British physicist, was rooted to earth's gravity in the Payload Operations Control Center here at the Johnson Space Center. He sat at a coffee table in one of the six scientists' rooms off the main control room. Spread before him on the table were his experiment-procedures book, a plastic model of the test equipment, a small calculator and a tape recorder, which he calls his ''electronic notebook.''

headline.main: 5 HOPEFULS FIND IT TOUGH TO FOLLOW JACKSON ACT

results.snippet: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson, in his third speech of the day, won standing applause from an audience of New Mexico Democrats, Charles T. Manatt, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, seemed impressed.    ''He gets better as the day...
results.lead_paragraph: When the Rev. Jesse Jackson, in his third speech of the day, won standing applause from an audience of New Mexico Democrats, Charles T. Manatt, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, seemed impressed. ''He gets better as the day goes along,'' Mr. Manatt told the audience at the $1,000-a-plate dinner. ''I'm glad we don't have a midnight show.'' As the remark suggests, this has seemed to be Mr. Jackson's week in the Democratic Presidential campaign. He came close to turning the national committee's Presidential Sweep, a five-city tour he and five other candidates completed here today, into the Jesse Jackson show.

headline.main: SOVIET LAUNCHING EXPLOSION AND SALYUT 7 LEAK

results.snippet: CONFIRMED   By JOHN F. BURNS    MOSCOW, Dec. 12 - Soviet space officials today confirmed that two astronauts ejected to safety when an ascent vehicle exploded on its Central Asian launching pad in September. They also confirmed that the manned...
results.lead_paragraph: CONFIRMED By JOHN F. BURNS MOSCOW, Dec. 12 - Soviet space officials today confirmed that two astronauts ejected to safety when an ascent vehicle exploded on its Central Asian launching pad in September. They also confirmed that the manned Salyut 7 orbital laboratory had a fuel leak about the same time that required the shutdown of part of the craft's maneuvering system. Both problems had been previously reported by United States intelligence officials who monitor Soviet space flights. Confirmation of the difficulties came in response to questions by Western reporters at a press conference attended by Vladimir A. Lyakhov and Aleksandr P. Aleksandrov, the crewmen who completed a 150- day flight aboard Salyut 7 on Nov. 23.

headline.main: NASA TO SEEK OBSERVERS TO FLY ON SHUTTLE

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it would propose regulations ''very soon'' on how it will select private citizens to be passengers on the space shuttle.    James M. Beggs, Administrator of the agency, said he...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it would propose regulations ''very soon'' on how it will select private citizens to be passengers on the space shuttle. James M. Beggs, Administrator of the agency, said he hoped to solicit the first applications from ''civilian passengers'' by early next year and expected the first flights carrying such passengers to occur ''as early as 1985.'' Preference will be given to writers, journalists, artists and others who can convey the excitement of what they observe to the public, he said.

headline.main: THE DEMOCRATS AND FOREIGN POLICY

results.snippet: FOR ALMOST TWO DECADES, the Democratic Party has been tearing itself apart over foreign and defense policy, first over Vietnam and later over detente with the Soviet Union. Now, to listen to the Democrats tell it, their views are more compatible...

byline.original: By Leslie H. GelbLeslie H. Gelb is The Times's national security correspondent based in Washington

results.lead_paragraph: FOR ALMOST TWO DECADES, the Democratic Party has been tearing itself apart over foreign and defense policy, first over Vietnam and later over detente with the Soviet Union. Now, to listen to the Democrats tell it, their views are more compatible than at any time in the last two decades and they are offering more cohesive ''Democratic alternatives'' to President Reagan's policies. The candidates and their advisers think President Reagan's style of conservatism and his policy flip-flops have made the world a more dangerous place, that the bulk of the American public is worried and that the peace issue will be at the top of voter concerns, along with the economy, in the 1984 elections.

headline.main: Space Station in the Ballot Box

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has long lobbied for a manned space station. Come election year, it may get its $20 billion wish.   Are there that many votes in space? Not usually. But Senator John Glenn, a former astronaut, is a...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has long lobbied for a manned space station. Come election year, it may get its $20 billion wish. Are there that many votes in space? Not usually. But Senator John Glenn, a former astronaut, is a space enthusiast, and Walter Mondale, when a senator, vigorously opposed the space shuttle. Suddenly the White House finds a bold new space initiative very appealing.

headline.main: GLENN CAMPAIGN STRUGGLES TO PUT IMAGE IN FOCUS

results.snippet: A moment earlier John Glenn had been speaking from atop a tree stump at a backyard Texas picnic, but now, as the line formed for hot dogs and chili sauce, he saw a woman pushing through the crowd toward him.    ''Sign this,'' she said, giving him...
results.lead_paragraph: A moment earlier John Glenn had been speaking from atop a tree stump at a backyard Texas picnic, but now, as the line formed for hot dogs and chili sauce, he saw a woman pushing through the crowd toward him. ''Sign this,'' she said, giving him a handwritten campaign poster, ''for my little boy, a future nuclear scientist.'' For nearly an hour the Ohio Democrat stood there, signing pamphlets, bumper stickers, scraps of paper, even napkins. It was, like many of the groups he has met in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, his crowd. At the end of a year in which many political professionals believe that former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has all but assured himself of winning the nomination, Mr. Glenn's advisers insist they still have the candidate with the broadest political appeal and the best chance of defeating Ronald Reagan next November, should the President run.

headline.main: GERMAN IS CRITICAL OF LIMITS ON EUROPEAN USE OF SPACELAB

results.snippet: The first foreigner on a United States spaceship said today he was pleased with the scientific results of the latest Columbia mission. But he criticized the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for not letting the Europeans make greater...
results.lead_paragraph: The first foreigner on a United States spaceship said today he was pleased with the scientific results of the latest Columbia mission. But he criticized the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for not letting the Europeans make greater use of Spacelab, which they built and donated. Ulf Merbold, the West German physicist who went on the mission, said, at a news conference attended by the entire crew: ''The return to Europe should be more. Spacelab is designed for 50 flights and NASA's return to Europe is just one half of one mission.''

headline.main: PatentsStacy V. Jones Simulator Of Gravity For Space

results.snippet: WASHINGTON  A N astronaut who is a physician has invented a suit to simulate in space the effects of normal gravity on the human circulatory system. The invention allows normal movement in a spacecraft.
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON A N astronaut who is a physician has invented a suit to simulate in space the effects of normal gravity on the human circulatory system. The invention allows normal movement in a spacecraft.

headline.main: BUSINESS DIGEST

results.snippet: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1983   The Economy    Retailers have enjoyed their best Christmas season in five years, with sales running 13 percent higher than a year ago and luxury goods showing an especially robust recovery. The gains have been made...
results.lead_paragraph: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1983 The Economy Retailers have enjoyed their best Christmas season in five years, with sales running 13 percent higher than a year ago and luxury goods showing an especially robust recovery. The gains have been made despite recent winter storms. (Page 29.) The nation's money supply fell $2 billion in the week ended Dec. 14, a decline that analysts said was steeper than expected. The large drop led to predictions that the Federal Reserve Board was not likely to tighten credit in the near future, but some analysts said monetary growth was so sluggish that it could imperil the recovery. (Page 29.) In their mid-November meeting, the Fed's Open Market Committee decided not to change monetary policy. But the Fed gave few clues of more recent policy. (32.)

headline.main: STICK TO POETRY: SOVIET CRITIC TELLS YEVTUSHENKO

results.snippet: Yevgeny A. Yevtushenko, one of the Soviet Union's most popular poets, has come under the harshest criticism of his career for his first novel, ''Berry Patches,'' among other things for the book's critical treatment of Stalin's mass roundup of...
results.lead_paragraph: Yevgeny A. Yevtushenko, one of the Soviet Union's most popular poets, has come under the harshest criticism of his career for his first novel, ''Berry Patches,'' among other things for the book's critical treatment of Stalin's mass roundup of land-owning peasants in the 1930's. A review of the novel in the current issue of the monthly literary magazine Nash Sovremennik calls it dishonest and immoral and says that it should never have been published. The book first appeared in the literary magazine Novy Mir early last year, and has been published as a paperback with a printing of nearly 2.5 million copies. When it first appeared it received a number of favorable reviews and quickly became a favorite in bookshops.

headline.main: AN INTERVIEW WITH JOHN GLENN, SENATOR AND FORMER ASTRONAUT

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from the transcript of an interview with Senator John Glenn by David Shribman:   Q. What do you think is the most important problem facing the United States over the next decade, and what new ideas can you bring to that...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the transcript of an interview with Senator John Glenn by David Shribman: Q. What do you think is the most important problem facing the United States over the next decade, and what new ideas can you bring to that problem? GLENN: I think there are two things right now that are most important. Of course, the one that overrides everything else is the question in people's minds as to whether we are drifting closer to war or to peace; what is our trend at the moment? Most people are very disturbed about this Administration, the Reagan Administration, and what they believe is a drift more toward the direction of hostilities than toward peace. With that regard, I have been putting forward for some time now a five-point arms control program that I think is doable. I think it's necessary, and I think it's in more detail than either the President or any of my competitors for this nomination on the Democratic side have proposed. It's a method of getting limitations, and moving on to reducing nuclear weapons, in forcing nuclear nonproliferation, of which I was the principal author of that law that was passed back in 1978, because it will do us little good to get control of nuclear weapons between ourselves and the Soviets if we find a dozen other nations have, in the meantime, received nuclear weapons capability. Q. What are the five points?

headline.main: AN ECONOMIC RECOVERY STIRS, AND A CAMPAIGN CURTAIN RISES

results.snippet: Productivity up, investment up, retail sales up, the inflation rate down, the stock market bullish - such were the signs of the nation's economic recovery of 1983. But there was a cloud in the picture: a $200 billion Federal deficit.   Moreover,...
results.lead_paragraph: Productivity up, investment up, retail sales up, the inflation rate down, the stock market bullish - such were the signs of the nation's economic recovery of 1983. But there was a cloud in the picture: a $200 billion Federal deficit. Moreover, the recovery did not spread its benefits uniformly over every part of the economy. Prosperous farmers continued to do well with the help of large Government subsidies, but for many smaller farmers the burden of high interest led to foreclosures. Unemployment, down from its peak in the recession, remained high by historic standards as the nation struggled with its shift from heavy industry to high technology, from factories that employed many unskilled workers to plants that required fewer and more skilled workers.

headline.main: Prediction: What'll Be The Big Events of '83?

results.snippet: The Procrastinators Club of America has issued its predictions for 1983.
results.lead_paragraph: The Procrastinators Club of America has issued its predictions for 1983.
